properties.entry:
Returns meters that match the combination of all values provided.

Quick Search will search both Meter Number and Device Name fields.

The search returns all meters that have values which start with the provided text. For example searching for any field that begins with "12" will return values such as 12, 1234 but will not return 1, 1123, or 112.

Queues

Queues handle messages between Service Manager and Network Manager that contain information for device creation, device editing, or data archival.
  • RFN Meter Archive Request: Meter data to be archived, sent from Network Manager to Service Manager.
  • RFN LCR Archive Request: LCR data to be archived, sent from Network Manager to Service Manager.
  • Gateway Archive Request: Initiates creation of an RF Gateway device, sent from Network Manager to Service Manager.
  • RF DA Archive Request: Initiates creation of an RF DA device, sent from Network Manager to Service Manager.
  • Gateway Data Request: Request for data about an RF Gateway, sent from Service Manager to Network Manager.
  • Gateway Data Response: RF Gateway data, sent from Network Manager to Service Manager.

Metrics

These metrics show how many messages are sent and received, and how efficiently they are being processed.
  • Archived Readings: The number of data readings that have been archived.
  • Processed Archive Requests: The number of messages that have been fully processed. (Each message may contain multiple data readings.)
  • Enqueued Count: The number of messages that have been pushed onto the queue since service start.
  • Dequeued Count: The number of messages that have been taken off the queue since service start.
  • Queue Size: The number of messages currently on the queue.
  • Average Enqueue Time: The average length of time a message waits in the queue for processing, since service start.

Displays all Notes matching the filter values selected. You can apply any of the following filters to the report:
  • Note Text - text contained within a note, case is ignored.
  • Device Selection - select one to many devices to filter the results.
    • All - no filtering by device.
    • Group - filter notes attached to any device within a device group.
    • Selected - filter notes attached to one or more selected individual device(s).
  • Create Date range - filter notes created between the start date and the end date.
  • Created By - filter notes created by any user or by a specific user.
    • Any User
    • Current User

The Device Configuration widget allows for the configuration of devices, data streaming, and meter programming.

Device Configuration – If the device is configured, the assigned configuration will be displayed along with options to Upload, Validate, or Remove the configuration. There is also an option to Change the configuration for the device.

Data Streaming – If Data Streaming is enabled on the system, a section will display showing the current data streaming configuration, along with the options to Configure or Remove.

Meter Programming – If Meter Programming is enabled on the system and the device supports Meter Programming, a section will display showing the current Program. If the device is not programmed, an option will display to Configure the programming.

The Network Information widget provides networking information for a device including the following:

Primary Forward – Primary Forward is determined by the node and is the gateway the node has chosen to provide its data every reporting interval.

Reverse Lookup – Reverse Lookup is determined by the software as the most likely gateway to successfully process an on demand function to the selected device.

The Primary Forward and Reverse Lookup are generally the same for a node. In instances where they are different, it is likely a node has switched gateways and the new routing data has not been received or processed by the Yukon software. If this is the case, the Comm Status will be Unknown until the new routing data has been received and the gateways match again.

Listed are gateways that risk exceeding their capacity to transmit data. Yellow implies the excess is near enough to have only some impact with message loss. Red implies there is a significant chance data will be lost.

Clicking on the gateway loading percentage will display a Data Streaming Summary for the selected gateway.
No gateways were found to be at risk of exceeding capacity to transmit data.

Select a Device Group to obtain data collection information for. Check the include disabled checkbox to include any disabled devices in the calculations. Click on the pie chart to view detailed device information. The data collection details are updated every 6 seconds by default. The Refresh button will force an update of the data collected (if data has not been collected in the last 15 minutes). The date/time displays the date/time that data collection was last updated.

Data Availability Status:
  • Available (Green) - Data has been received for these devices within the desired number of days.
  • Expected (Blue) - Data has been received for these devices within 7 days.
  • Outdated (Orange) - Data has been received for these devices within 14 days.
  • Unreported (Grey) - Data has not been received for these devices for over 14 days.

Select a Scenario, Control Area, or Program to obtain operational information for Demand Response devices. Click on the pie chart to view detailed device information. The asset availability details are updated every 30 minutes by default. The Refresh button will force an update of the asset availability details (this is available every 15 minutes). The date/time displays the date/time when operational status was last updated.

Asset Availability Status:
  • Active (Green) - Devices have returned a positive value for appliance run time at some point in the previous {0}{1}.
  • Opted Out (Blue) - Devices have been taken out of service and are no longer responding to events.
  • Inactive (Orange) - Devices have returned the value zero for every appliance run time interval in the previous {0}{1}.
  • Unavailable (Grey) - Devices have not provided any run time data in the previous {2} hours.
No devices were found for Device Group: {0}.

The Infrastructure Warnings widget periodically evaluates devices associated with the communications network such as RF gateways, RF relays, CCUs or repeaters. Results of the evaluations will produce informational or warning messages about specific conditions that may require investigation. A summary of the devices with and without warnings will be displayed near the top of the widget with the device type being a link to more detail.
  • Devices without warnings (Green) - Number of devices without any of the below mentioned warning types.
  • Devices with warnings (Orange) - Number of devices with warnings.
Click on the "See All" link to view all current infrastructure warnings. A list of the 10 most recent warnings will be displayed below. The Duration indicates approximately how much time has passed since the warning first occurred. Hover over the Duration value to see the exact time that the warning first occurred.
The infrastructure warnings are updated every 15 minutes, by default. The Refresh button will force an update if data has not been updated in the last 5 minutes. The date/time next to the Refresh button displays the date/time that the warnings were last updated.

The following is a list of the types of warnings that are being evaluated:
  • Gateway connection status – Warning condition produced if a gateway has not communicated with the Yukon software in a specified period of time. It may indicate a bulk communications issue with that particular gateway.
  • Duplicate gateway color found - Warning condition produced when two gateways on the RF network have the same color setting. The condition indicates a misconfigured gateway.
  • Gateway is in failsafe mode – Warning condition produced when a gateway enters failsafe mode. A gateway enters this mode when it is unable to execute the gateway application code or the application is restarted in quick succession. This can be caused by a series of outages, or by a problem with the gateway hardware or software. Note that gateways in failsafe mode will only communicate with Yukon software and will not gather data from the RF nodes. After 24 hours in failsafe mode, the gateway will automatically attempt to boot back into normal mode.
  • Gateway total connected nodes – Condition produced when a gateway reaches a specified total node count that could affect the network’s ability to fully absorb a neighboring gateway’s nodes should it be needed. A low-severity warning is issued for this condition. A high-severity warning is issued when a gateway reaches the maximum total node count supported by the device.
  • Gateway data streaming capacity – Condition produced when a gateway is approaching or has surpassed the available bandwidth provided for the data streaming functionality. A low-severity warning is issued when a gateway reaches the defined data streaming capacity limits. This condition is primarily informational since a fully loaded gateway should not impact the performance of the network. A high-severity warning is issued when a gateway has significantly exceeded the defined data streaming capacity and intervention may be needed to reduce any impacts on network performance due to this condition.
  • Gateway ready node count - Condition produced when a gateway drops below the expected minimum ready node count.
  • Relay outage event – Warning condition produced when a ‘Last Gasp’ outage notification is received from a relay. This condition will automatically clear when the relay’s restoration notification is received.
  • PLC CCU communication status – Warning condition produced when ten consecutive messages targeting the specified CCU fail to be delivered. This may indicate a bulk communication problem between the Yukon software and the device.
  • PLC Repeater communication status - Warning condition produced when ten consecutive messages targeting the specified Repeater fail to be delivered. This indicates a communication problem between the Yukon software and the device.
You are not authorized to access this widget.

The Comm Channel Queue Counts widget displays up to 3 (default) months of historical data for a maximum number of 5 (default) communication channels (not inclusive of RF Meters). The number of months and communication channel limits may be modified at a system level in the Yukon Configuration Settings. The communication channels are selected when the widget is created and are used to populate the graph each time the widget is loaded. Temporarily change the selected communication channels using the picker. To permanently change the default selected communication channels, edit the dashboard and select different communication channels, and click save. The Comm Channel Queue Counts details are updated every 6 seconds. The Refresh button will force an update of the data in {0}.

RF Broadcast Performance widget provides summary of expected RF LCR response performance from the previous 5 days of Demand Response test message events. The RF Broadcast performance widget is updated every 15 minutes, by default. The Refresh button will force an update if data has not been updated in the last 1 minute. The date/time next to the Refresh button displays the date/time when the performance was last updated.

Select a predefined Trend to view up to 1 month of archived data. Click on the zoom buttons 1d, 1w or 1m to view archived data for 1 day, 1 week and 1 month respectively. Use the slider bars to change the start and/or end date of archived data displayed in the trend. Click "Details" to navigate to the full featured Web Trends display for the selected trend. The trend updates every 30 minutes by default. The Refresh button will force an update of the trend data (this is available every 15 minutes).
* Display is limited to 10 Active or Scheduled programs.
No programs are currently running or scheduled to run in the next control day.

View program information for recent or scheduled control events. Information displayed includes program name, origin, gear used, start and stop time. A maximum of 10 events are displayed; today's events, scheduled events, and up to previous 7 days of events. If more than 10 events are scheduled or have occured in the last 7 days, the list will be truncated at the oldest event.
Start or Stop time with asterisk (*) - the start or stop date are different from program start date.
The program history is updated every 1 minute, by default. The Refresh button will force an update if data has not been updated in the last 30 seconds.

Origin of program start:
  • Manual – Program started manually from Yukon Web Application or Tabular Data Console (legacy).
  • Automatic - Program started via control area trigger and timed start program.
  • Unknown - Origin not known.
Origin color indicates program state:
  • Active (Green) - Program is currently active and running.
  • Scheduled (Orange) - Program is scheduled to run in the future.
  • Inactive (Black) - Program is complete or inactive.
Click on the "View Details" link to view all scheduled, current day and previous 7 days program events.
